author: Staff Reporter
text:
Aam Aadmi Party on Thursday cleared speculation that the party will not enter into any pre-poll alliance in Punjab. The Punjab Pradesh Congress Committee (PPCC) had reportedly proposed an alliance in the agrarian State after the success of a grand alliance in Bihar and there were reports that PPCC members had even tried to meet AAP’s Punjab unit to discuss the possibility.

The AAP members, however, said they have never had anything to do with the Congress. “We are not allying with anyone. The AAP has nothing to do with the Congress and going by Thursday’s rally response, one can measure the strength of the party in Punjab,” said Ashish Talwar, political advisor to Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal.

The State will go to the polls in early 2017.

However, the AAP did form the government in Delhi with the Congress’ outside support for 49-days after the 2013 Assembly elections. Party sources said going into with an alliance had hit the party’s image in the past. “When AAP formed the government with the Congress in Delhi, it didn’t go down well with people. Recently, when Arvind Kejriwal shared the stage with Lalu Prasad in Bihar, political rivals used it as an opportunity,” said an AAP leader.

But with the report of infighting within the AAP’s Punjab unit rife, the party had to dispatch leaders of the Delhi unit to oversee the campaigning in Punjab. After Delhi, the AAP has a strong voter base in Punjab as all the four MPs from the party are from the State. Though the party in August suspended two of its MPs over anti-party activities, but Mr. Talwar maintained that the party is going strong in Punjab.
title: ‘No pre-poll tie-up in Punjab’
